body:
Example:
```
2022-05-25T15:10:36.0934858Z  1940: stdout FAILED:
2022-05-25T15:10:36.3957247Z --- log/check-expected	2022-05-25 08:10:36.094059000 -0700
2022-05-25T15:10:36.3963026Z +++ log/check-generated	2022-05-25 08:10:36.093076800 -0700
2022-05-25T15:10:36.3964990Z @@ -1,9 +1,9 @@
2022-05-25T15:10:36.3965801Z - Date == Thu, 09 Nov 2010 14:49:00 GMT[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4120437Z - Server == test with trailing space[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4121768Z - Content-Type == text/html[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4123345Z - Content-Length == 0[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4161557Z - Location == /19400002[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4164829Z -- Set-Cookie == onecookie=data; (0/3)[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4170663Z -- Set-Cookie == secondcookie=2data; (1/3)[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4172650Z -- Set-Cookie == cookie3=data3; (2/3)[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4173488Z - Fold == is folding a line[CR][LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4174288Z + Date == Thu, 09 Nov 2010 14:49:00 GMT[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4175193Z + Server == test with trailing space[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4177754Z + Content-Type == text/html[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4178462Z + Content-Length == 0[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4179224Z + Location == /19400002[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4179943Z +- Set-Cookie == onecookie=data; (0/3)[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4181896Z +- Set-Cookie == secondcookie=2data; (1/3)[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4208438Z +- Set-Cookie == cookie3=data3; (2/3)[LF]
2022-05-25T15:10:36.4209756Z + Fold == is folding a line[LF]
```

git text conversion is explicitly unset for test* files so i don't think that could be it.

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/462196e6b4a47f924293a0e26b8e9c23d37ac26f/tests/data/.gitattributes#L1

On my Windows computer test1940 file stdout section (ie source of "expected") retains its original line endings which makes sense given -crlf

![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/965580/170431950-e578e80b-a6fc-4d79-a5d1-ef21388dd091.PNG)

the xml is loaded in binary:

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/462196e6b4a47f924293a0e26b8e9c23d37ac26f/tests/getpart.pm#L190-L196

then individual parts can be retrieved with getpart which doesn't seem to do any conversion. the only place i see a conversion is if mode="text" is set for stdout, which it isn't.

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/462196e6b4a47f924293a0e26b8e9c23d37ac26f/tests/runtests.pl#L4364-L4373

either i missed a conversion somewhere or something external is converting it.

Thanks for the analysis so far @jay , but maybe a stupid question: why are we expecting headers to terminate with LF anyway? Aren't headers normally terminated with CRLF and this is how we do it in other tests usually? Maybe this is the reason the problem only surfaces this time.

`runtests.pl` compares files, it doesn't know how they are made. Our test files hold the binary contents, so if not said otherwise the comparisons are done exactly byte by byte. For several comparisons we can mark them as `mode="text`" and then the script unifies the newlines to CRLF before comparing, with the idea that they should work fine for text files on any system, including windows. Like for `<file>` comparisons.

And again, this test works on *some* Windows builds which puzzles me. And the output @jay showed above is also weird since it seems to show two identical outputs (both using CRLF newlines) but still diff thinks they differ. So how come?

> why are we expecting headers to terminate with LF anyway?

"headers" in (HTTP) tests are provided in the tests themselves so they are provided the way the test makes them. Some are LF some are CRLF.

> And again, this test works on *some* Windows builds which puzzles me. And the output @jay showed above is also weird since it seems to show two identical outputs (both using CRLF newlines) but still diff thinks they differ. So how come?

Does it? I think the expected output in the diff is shown with CRLF while it is specified as LF in the test file. Also the generated test output is LF, as desired and shown in the diff.

> Does it?

No I was wrong. I must have hallucinated. The question is then why it doesn't have CRLF there since it is marked as text...

> > Does it?
> 
> 
> 
> No I was wrong. I must have hallucinated. The question is then why it doesn't have CRLF there since it is marked as text...

It is not marked as text as shown in @jay's screenshot.

And another information: non of the AppVeyor builds using msys are actual native Win32 cross-builds. All of them compile to the msys-specific Linux emulation layer. Only the VS builds there and the Azure Windows builds are Win32 native by cross-compiling from msys using mingw. I guess it is time to make this distinction visible in the job names.

issue.title: DISABLE test 1940 on the Cirrus CI Windows builds

body:
> It is not marked as text as shown in @jay's screenshot.

With **marked** I mean using that property in the test case. Like this on line 50:

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/a77d14d22ae93aa15670522e453f78744649b8cc/tests/data/test1940#L50

I think the screenshot shows the stdout data isn't treated the way that the test case tells it to.

> And another information: non of the AppVeyor builds using msys are actual native Win32 cross-builds

But why does that matter? I seem to recall that they need the text mode set nonetheless?

> > It is not marked as text as shown in @jay's screenshot.
> 
> 
> 
> With **marked** I mean using that property in the test case. Like this on line 50:
> 
> 
> 
> https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/a77d14d22ae93aa15670522e453f78744649b8cc/tests/data/test1940#L50
> 
> 
> 
> I think the screenshot shows the stdout data isn't treated the way that the test case tells it to.

Interesting, then I don't understand why he showed it without the text mode on stdout above:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/231943/170594517-caac7628-07c4-4a6e-9d84-ad25188cd265.jpeg)

> > And another information: non of the AppVeyor builds using msys are actual native Win32 cross-builds
> 
> 
> 
> But why does that matter? I seem to recall that they need the text mode set nonetheless?

I am pointing this out while I am not sure about its relevance, because I think this is an important distinction to keep in mind since it **could** be influencing file modes, stdout/stderr redirection and similar things.

The msys environment is basically POSIX oriented and uses LF, while mingw builds (even from msys) use CRLF.

It looks like c9b60f0 which landed 2 days ago changed the mode to text, so now it is correct that check-expected show [CR][LF] and check-generated (which is generated by lib1940) is still [LF]? 

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/10cd69623a544c83bae6d90acdf141981ae53174/tests/libtest/lib1940.c#L57-L58
